NOTICE OF PUBLIC HEARING

The Board of Education of the County of Mason will hold a Public Hearing regarding the ten (10) year Comprehensive Educational Facility Plan (CEFP) which will chart the course for the school system through the year 2030. The plan must be approved by the County Board of Education, the West Virginia State Board of Education, and the School Building Authority of West Virginia. The CEFP includes, but is not limited to grade configurations, enrollment history, projections and enrollment sizes for schools, number of schools that can be operated within the school budget and conditions of schools.

The hearing will be held on Monday, September 28, 2020 at 6:00 PM at the Central Office located at 1 Education Lane, Point Pleasant, WV. The meeting will be broadcast on the Mason County Schools Facebook Page.

This hearing is to provide an opportunity for the public to ask questions about the plan, provide comments regarding the proposed plan and/or submit statements on the proposed plan.

Spotlight on Beale Elementary

Beale Elementary’s annual Wax Museum continued virtually this year with PK through 6th grade students participating. PK-2 students chose a favorite book character and students in 3rd-6th gave a biographical portrayal of their chosen person. The staff at Beale was simply overwhelmed with the outcome, especially this year. Our Families worked with students to create videos of their presentations (When possible) and submitted them over the course of two days via the Beale PTO Facebook page. To say it was an emotional experience viewing the submissions and working with our Beale families on so many other activities throughout this time of distance cannot really capture our feelings. We have truly come to appreciate that Beale Elementary is not a building — it’s the culmination of the families & community we have the privilege to serve. We could not be prouder of our extended Beale Family.

This is an overview of their projects #MasonProud #LoveMyWVSchool

First Grade teachers at NHES are having families participate in Family Fun Projects to help make learning fun during these unsettling times. Information from Jack Cullen,
Superintendent of Mason County Schools

School buildings may be closed but learning continues in Mason County Schools. We are committed to staying connected with our families, students, and community members. Distance learning and various activities will continue through the remainder of the school year. We appreciate all the families who are helping their children stay focused on their studies at home, while also teaching them the meaning of social distancing. We know this is a stressful time and all staff members will continue to support our students remotely by meeting their physical, emotional, and academic needs. We are working on plans which will allow families to return school-owned items and pick up personal items at the end of the current school year. Thank you for supporting our school system.

shared_text:
Tasty Blend Foods, Inc.
January 6 at 9:52 AM ·

This past Friday we had some special visitors. Beverly Glaze, the Director of Food Service, and the Food Service Team from Mason County schools here in West Virginia, visited Tasty Blend Foods.

They toured our facility, including our new bakery that produces over 15,000 school breakfast sandwiches each hour. Students in Mason County will be eating Teays Valley biscuit sandwiches for breakfast several times this month. They also worked in our test kitchen on a new item that may find its way to the breakfast menu in Mason county…Mothman Dippers. Stay tuned.

It’s a blessing for us here at Tasty Blend Foods to partner with such good people.

post_text: Mason County Schools promoting education and business #CTE
shared_text:
Rhonda Braden Tennant is with Jared Billings and Cheryl Buck Moore.
September 26, 2019 at 11:37 PM ·

There was a business meeting held today at our career center. Board president Jared Billings & I were able to attend along with Superintendent Cullen. There were representatives from many of the major businesses in our area. The intent was to discuss how our school system & our businesses can work together to provide maximum employment opportunities for our students. We listened to an update on the coal/gas plant project. 🤞🏻 Jared & I were particularly interested in what Kathy D’Antoni from the state department had to say. Supposedly, there is money available to help expand programs at our career center!! We’ll be talking to her more about this! Culinary students from the career center prepared a delicious lunch for us! #yummy

post_text: Happy Retirement Louease Sayre
shared_text:
Rhonda Braden Tennant is with Walter Raynes and 5 others.
September 26, 2019 at 7:22 PM ·

Friends, colleagues, & family members gathered at New Haven School tonight to honor retired teacher, Louease Sayre. Superintendent Jack Cullen had Mrs. Sayre as his first & second grade teacher. Louease says she stays busy, but she misses teaching. I’ll never forget the time that I spent working alongside Louease, & I’ll never forget standing alongside her in the cold & rain on the picket lines during the teacher strikes. I wouldn’t be surprised to see her standing amidst her friends again, fighting for teachers’ benefits, should the need arise. We love you, Mrs. Sayre! Thank you for your many years of dedication to educating our children! Enjoy your much deserved time off, but don’t forget to visit! ❤️
